wire.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: thin metal in the form of a thread, or a piece of this
wire.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a piece of metal like this, used for carrying electrical currents or signals
wire.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a piece of electronic recording equipment, usually worn secretly on someone’s clothes
wire.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: Use a piece of fine wire to clear the obstruction.

Electrical impulses are sent down the copper wire.

We drew up outside a compound surrounded by a wire fence.

The coil of barbed wire will be used for a fence.

wire.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to connect wires inside a building or piece of equipment so that electricity can pass through
wire.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Check that the plug has been wired up properly.
wire.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to connect electrical equipment to the electrical system using wires
wire.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The CD player had been wired up to the car’s cigarette lighter.
wire.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to attach a piece of recording equipment to a person or room, especially secretly
wire.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: to send a telegram to someone
wire.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: to fasten two or more things together using wire
wire.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: The poles had all been wired together.
wire.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to send money electronically from one bank to another
wire.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Prosecutors said Burks moved $45,000 to his girlfriend and wired $13,300 to a bank account in Florida.
wire.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to connect something to a computer system or another piece of equipment
wire.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Her laptop is wired up to a router, and the other computers in the house run on wireless adaptors.
